segments.text: This is an interview with Colonel Herbert L. Curry, United States Marine Corps, by Brian W. Icarus on April 29, 1989, at the Trigon Building, Texas A&M University, College Station, Texas, concerning the Vietnam War.
In the interest of accumulating knowledge about the war, I am going to donate this tape to Texas A&M Oral History Collection in the University Archives.
Is that all right with you, sir?
Yes, sir.

Sir, you had previously stated in the interview given by James W. Hodges, Jr. on November 29, 1988, that your first experience in Vietnam in 1963 was with the 3rd Recon Battalion and the underwater demolition teams of the Navy.
It has been stated by other sources that during these years, even the special warfare units had difficulties performing.
Would you please expand on that, sir?
Yes, I will.
First, under the conditions that I was operating, we didn't have difficulties before me, at least not difficulties with the South Vietnamese.
We operated from the board ship on a daily basis.
The underwater demolition folks conducted hydrographic surveys from the high water mark of the beach out to the sea.

or possible landing sites or landing beaches my platoon and i conducted reconnaissance from the high water mark of the beach up to 10 miles inward we would go in select routes of egress determine trafficability away from the beach select terrain objectives recon towns villages airfields
any type of military that was placed in that area.
The only difficulty that we encountered was that there would be Vietnamese in the area, Vietnamese military in the area.
They were unaware that we were operating in there at the same time.
There was not a communications set up between the ship that I was operating from
and the local Vietnamese military forces ashore.
So we were operating independently, and sometimes we would have a chance meeting with Vietnamese, and they weren't aware that we were in the area.
On one occasion, I was on a road about five or six miles inland, and coming around at the end was a military jeep with an army Vietnamese captain.
stopped and said, hey, we've got a big battle going on just around the curve and over that hill.
And we had no knowledge of that, so we had no intelligence.
And Vietnam was in a war at that time, and yet the US forces were in there operating.
So did I have trouble operating?
No, I didn't, because I was operating from sea on a daily basis.
My logistical support was there.
We were well taken care of.

But as far as any interface with the Vietnamese, we didn't have that, nor did we have any intelligence being given to us about what the area was like or was there any enemy forces in the area at that time.
I understand it's not the recon's mission to engage the enemy, but were there such encounters?
Yes.
We had a couple of encounters.
One time we were in the Marble Mountain area, and we received some gunfire, and we immediately departed the area, got back to our rubber boats, and went out to sea.
Another time we were in the Mekong Delta area, south of Vung Tau,
Half of my platoon got pinned down for an excess of a day.
We were drawn from the mangrove swamps.
We were on the beach, and the tide was out, and the tidal flap was such, or the tidal range was such, or the beach gradient was such that we couldn't get boats in to evacuate the people.
So we had to remain undercover throughout the day until the tide came in and we could evacuate the people.
Yes, it was our mission not to engage
We were strictly to have thousands of them.
Sir, what were the basic differences between activities while you were a platoon commander of a recon unit and a company commander of an infantry unit?
Which benefited you the most in dealing with the war?
Well, I can't say that one benefited me more than the other.
Because I had been in Vietnam as a second lieutenant, I knew something about the people.
I knew what the country and the planet were like.
And that gave me some first-hand knowledge on how to operate there.
I came back several years later as a captain and a company commander.
I had more experience at that time.
Plus, I'd gone through three weeks of specialized Marine Corps training at Camp Hillary, California.
which was to prepare people to go into Vietnam.
We had courses on, classes on the culture of the people, the do's and don'ts, and how to react with people, because we were over there to win the hearts and minds, as well as to win military.
We also had infiltration courses, courses that trained us in detecting and avoiding moving traps and mines.
So I felt that I was pretty well-prepared when I went to Vietnam.
Still, there is nothing like on-the-job experience in combat whenever you get over that.
Nothing truly compares you for everything in combat.
So when you're asking for a comparison between being a company commander in combat and being a platoon commander with reconnaissance equipment as a second lieutenant, there is no comparison.
All right, so I guess that will kind of lead into my next question now.
On your return to Vietnam in 1968, what were the noticeable differences then and your first experience in 1963?
In 1963, I had gone in.
One of the missions had gone in to the Bay Airfield.
or the military air base there in the northern portion of South Vietnam.
It was basically a sleepy village, oriental village.
The airfield, although there was a war going on, was fairly enacted by the U.S.
I was amazed when I flew in.
in 1968, January of 1968.
As I recall, there had been another airstrip prepared parallel to the original airstrip.
It was an air base in the city of Busting Rock City.
I was really, I was amazed
what America could do when it was mobilized and eventually made.
We had rocket crushers, postal services, clubs, exchanges, large organizations, lots of jets flying in and out, coming in on those runways.
The transformation was like day in, night out.
Is there any different from what it was like in 1963, as in
that you were located down in them.
But I guess the real question I'm asking is the attitude in the people and, I guess, the change in the war atmosphere.
I didn't have that much contact with the people in 1968 and 1969.
When I was there in 1963, the people still lived throughout the countryside.
because the war was not at the intensity that it was in 68 and 69.

But when I got there in 68, I found that we still had Vietnamese living in the name, and they were allowed to travel Route 1, but there were checkpoints that controlled their travel, and they all actively seized at nighttime.
Around the name, people still lived in villages
But we had had what we called the CAP program at that time.
That was Combined Action.
But we took a squad of Marines and had them living at each village to train them in self-defense.
The people would work their bills and crops in the daytime, and then they would return to their village, and all movement would cease after dark.
Anything we knew was considered hostile for those Vietnamese, US forces, as well as the
the local forces, what we call the PLs, I guess that's the popular forces, that were defending their little village of Hamlet.

Later on in the year, when I moved up to the northern I-Corps, in the area from Guaviette north and Guaviette west of the Laotian border, I found that there were no villagers or people living in villages.
They had all been
taken from the countryside and taken to resettlement areas.
These are camps that the U.S., I guess in conjunction with the U.S. Army, had constructed where they relocated everyone and they lived there.
They lived there until the war was over.
So in Northern I-Corps, there was no local populace out in the countryside.
If we saw anyone, he was hostile.
He was considered the authority of the leaves.
Did this have any conflict with such villages or groups of Indians such as the Montagnards who were really not active in the war?
I didn't get up into the mountain area where the Montagnards were working.
To my knowledge, they were not resettled.
I think they remain in the mountains.
Special forces working there.
They were not located in the area.
So I just don't have any knowledge or information.
In the field, I understand that many
the commanding officers were thought of as kings, and that whatever they said was the ultimate word.
Did you feel or see any such power?
Oh, absolutely.
I can call their lives.
I can determine when they can go out of the field, when they can return to the United States.
I found when I took over my company
conditions as far as the welfare of the Marines were cautious.
Sanitation was poor.
Personal sanitation was poor.
They weren't well fed, and there were ways to take care of the troops whenever they were in the field.
You required them to go out there and cut their hair.
You required them to shave every day.

we operated in the field continuously very seldom did we ever go back to a camp area where we could change clothes and take a shower when we did that was the first thing we did but also had fresh clothes blown into us where we just take off our old clothes
put them back on and put them on a helicopter from shipping out to Washington and fresh them.
I had a different type of rations in there other than the old C rations that we made.
They were called the B rations.
You got the dehydrated foods, hamburger patties, rice, ketchup, mustard, beans, things like that to supplement the C rations.
The C rations
is a high-nutrition, well-balanced ration.
But it gets old.
There are 12 types of meals, and that's all you get.
And I was determined when I got there to eat those meals to keep my health up.
And I found after three months in the field that I was even being selective in what I ate.
And when you become selective, then you don't get that balanced diet that you ate in the spring.
When that happens, people get sores.
They get injured.
Those injuries become sores, and you might have to evacuate someone to be treated because you get big sores.
With the change of diet, we've corrected all of that.
Another example, during the monsoons when it's so wet, you can get immersion, but you stay wet all the time.
I had people...
Our eyes should be on three pairs of socks, and we changed three times a day.
Me on the move, your feet would get wet every time we would stop and take your socks off.
But on a fresh pair, you'd rain those socks out and tuck them down on the inside of your trousers where your body would cause the moisture to evaporate.
So you always had a dry pair when we were back in Iowa.

tactical position not on the move or have certain forces out that means you have certain a certain percentage of your company my company in fact i'd have to take your boots and socks off use foot powder and let there be there i think you do that all day every day whenever they weren't uh on the move that's a fairly emergent problem but had i not done something like that people would have well i
Whenever I took over my company, people were being medevaced on the helicopter that I came in on because they had a mission.
Did you command your men, or how did you motivate them to fight?
Well, I obviously commanded them.
As in, how did you command and motivate them to fight?
First of all, I...
I sat high standards.
I maintained those standards.
When I took over the company, I felt it was a drag tag outfit.
They had long hair.
They had not shaven in days, maybe a week.
The previous company commander had allowed these conditions to exist.
I felt their morale was down.
I went in there and raised the standards.
I said, when you're not in contact with the enemy, we will shave every day.
We got haircuts.
We had flippers sent out to us so that whenever we weren't fighting, we could get haircuts and maintain our hygiene.
It didn't take long for the troops to realize that I was taken care of.
And whenever you're doing down, they'll fight for you.
But by maintaining standards and enforcing them, that required them to execute.
When you require people to execute, they'll fight for you in combat.
Bringing in better food to take care of.
Any time we were on the move or I had people out operating independently, I would honor them.
They contact with them constantly by radio, asking them where they were.
Usually, let's say I was moving my rifle company five miles in the jungle.
I'm the guy steering the train, so to speak.
Everyone else tunes out.
He's in charge, you don't have to worry about him anymore.
We might be strung out over three miles, and I would radio back to the plume commanders periodically and ask them where they were.
I kept the pressure on them so that they would have to keep up with where they were.
They might be a half mile or a mile behind me, but if something happened to me, I was knocked out, one of them would have to take over.
They would have to call in the artillery and aircraft.
They had to know where they were to do that.
And that was part of the training program that I went through.
So that they would know where they were.
Was this motivational?
or the level of motivation that they felt, is it any different or any lower or higher than that of an individual coming out of, say, boot camp?
I'm not sure there's any thing as motivational as coming out of boot camp for a young Marine.
He has proven himself to be a Marine.
And he's extremely proud of that.
War and combat in the war is a different situation.
You come out of there knowing that you survived.
And that's a different type of, that's a relief as opposed to a motivation.
After an engagement or a battle, I can assure you that
everyone was on the emotional high.
I won't call it motivation, but the adrenaline would be up and let's say your battle ended at 5 o'clock in the afternoon.
You may stay awake all night being unable to sleep or may not be able to go to sleep until 3 or 4 in the morning because of the emotional high that you experienced after the battle.
Was the
level of motivation or the way in which you commanded your men any different from the way you led them in 1963?
Well, the situation was entirely different in 68 and 69 than it was in 63.
We didn't have the same problems we were engaged in.
combat or the threat of engaging with the enemy did not exist in 1963.
So I would say, yes, there was a difference.
And as a captain in 68 and 69, I was more experienced, more seasoned.
You had to handle people better.
I had a bigger bag of tools to use in 1968 than I did in 1963.
Sir?
Were there any problems with sexual harassment of the Vietnamese or the torching of villages?
To my knowledge, there was no problem with sexual harassment.
Again, we were operating in a no-man's country where everyone was hostile.
There were no females there, as I said, indicated they were back in the resettlement camps.
Those camps were not guarded by U.S. forces, so there were no females around, according to Mark.
Torture, I'm aware of situations where other people got in trouble because they allowed prisoners of war to be tortured.
I know in my country, I was told after I took over,
That's company commander that after a big fight.
Pick up some of the guys.
Rock them hoping that they would die.
Because they had their good buddy killed.
Frustrated.
They really didn't want to take.
I know of no one in particular.
or any specific example of an arpeggio that means he was killed by anyone in my company.
If that did occur, the commanding officer should not have let it occur.
And in fairness to him, these could have been sea stories, and troops like to embellish things and go on here, unfortunately.
that you want to take prisoners of war.
They're a source of intelligence.
You get those guys and you evacuate them on a helicopter back to the intelligence agencies as quickly as you can.
During my tour, I know of no atrocities that were committed anywhere within the 3rd Marine Committee.

Before I went up to the northern part of Vietnam and took over my company, a captain who had the company up in the 3rd Marines was sent down to be named the court-martial because he had torched the village.
He stayed in the same hooch with me.
I thought he was waiting for his court-martial.
He was convicted of torching the village.
But he was given no punishment, obviously in his career.
But as he told the panel of colonels that sat on him, the court martians, you take, you go into a village or you're patrolling an area and you take fire, rifle fire out of there every day.
You go in, there's no one there, except some local villagers.
I think you know that they're hiding for the income.
They've got caves and tunnels and so forth.
What happened, I believe, in this case, I think one day they were taking some fire.
They probably had some casualties.
When they went through, someone just reached up there and lit a flash through the village.
After he explained that, I remember his words, you old colonels back here in the rear don't know what it's like going out there every day and getting shot at from this one particular village.
Pretty soon, and you know the Viet Cong are there, and that the villages are hiding them.
So I just watched the Marine Corps court-martialing though.
It was wrong.
And so he's crazy.
There is another, there's a colonel in the Marine Corps right now who was interviewed on this TV series, a documentary on Vietnam.
And I believe there was a similar type of boy in there.
He may have clutched the legs.
I'm not sure.
I know he didn't get court-martialed.
But yes, that type of thing went on.
And the guy that's in the field and lives with it on a daily basis has a different perspective of the people that are in the rear.
What looks black and white to people from a distance isn't quite black and white when you're out there and you're facing them.
Is there kind of a...

defend their their acts by by knowing that the villagers supported them feeling that they did i mean you can be so so nice to the villagers but when they go out and they support the uh the vietcong or whatever you know vietnamization doesn't even work well they uh they weren't defending their acts
And they didn't kill any of the villagers.
They got the villagers out of the village before they tortured them.
But by eliminating where they lived, the villagers had to move on, and that was no longer a trouble spot.
That was their thought process, the torture.
How did the generation of soldiers respond to the war?
Some responded extremely well, others not well at all.
I don't know if the difference is a matter of education or awareness.
Some people are natural fighters.
They come from the city and they just love a good fight.
opposed to fighting, but they got drafted.
Those guys did make themselves as your good friends in combat.
As we know, we had a lot of people go to Canada.
We had draft fighters.
We had people that demonstrated.
It was your large college crowd that did that.
With the media that is available nowadays, it's much easier to generate support for a movement than it was, let's say, in 1941 during the Second World War.
It was not a popular war.
Most people didn't understand why we were over there and fighting.
Anyone who didn't understand that probably was reluctant to go over there.
Those that really put any thought into it, I'd say would be lucky to go there.
Except some people had to get in the Marines, where to get away from the bad way of life, where they were brought up.
And I actually, I had Marines under me who just thrived on being in combat.
I had others that did not.
You had stated in your previous interview that there's,
You didn't really know of any problems with fragging.
You had heard of incidences.
But was there a level of instruction or a low level of instruction that the lieutenants did not receive or did receive before they went into Vietnam?
About fragging?
Well, no, not about fragging.
somewhat like about leading and having their men follow them and not having enough experience.
Well, in the Marine Corps, we send all of our junior officers to basic schools where they're trained as infantrymen.
Then they're sent into their various schools for their various specialties.
That was a six-month-long school.
the top second lieutenants, the basics of the Marine Corps, from maintaining a vehicle to the supply system to leadership, many hours of leadership and tactics.
So yes, the young leaders or the young officers in the Marine Corps were prepared before they went in there.
You still have people
that aren't the best leaders, but get thrown into a situation where they don't lead well, and they could get cracked in a case like that.
A guy that was a typical chicken and uncomfortable with the troops for some reason could get cracked.
possibly even staff not commissioned officers could be, I don't know.
The fragging that I heard about was always back in the rear area, a base camp, so to speak, where you had a large transit population going in and out.
These were people that were avoiding going out into the combat units.
They were the recalcitrants.
I don't guess they might have retaliated.
I have no friends and no one by name that was fractured.
You're talking about the staff positions.
What was the general feeling towards the rear echelon people, being that they had never seen
the front line?
Well, I don't know how to answer that, mainly because I didn't have any feelings one way or the other about it.
I had my job to do, and I was out there doing it.
The people in the rear had to provide the support for me and the intelligence.
So they were providing a vital function for me.
Turn that off just a second.
There was the standard joke around about the USO shows like Bob Hope and the others and Margaret and so forth.
that would come into Vietnam.
It was always the guys in the rear that got to go to those shows, and never the guys in the field.
The guys up winning the war never got to enjoy St. Bob Hope and Aunt Margaret or something like that.
And so in that regard, there was resentment for the folks in the field.
I pertain to, let's say, big decision-making,
when a big operation is going to happen and a general officer makes a decision, the general officer is not fighting on the front line.

How is that felt by many of the people on the front line when they had to follow somebody who didn't really, or in their mind, they didn't feel that he knew the situation, what was going on in the front line?
I'm not sure that anyone even thought like that until I didn't know what the situation was.

We all hoped that the general knew what he was doing, and that any mission that we were sent on was a valid mission, because there was always the possibility that you would lose someone, and you didn't want to lose someone for a mission that was executed on time.
Yes, sir.
What was the general consensus pertaining to the way people demonstrated back in the United States against the war?
Well, I don't think you can say there's a general consensus.
If you were a liberal, you would say that the demonstrations were good and you were all for them.
If you were a conservative, you would say that the demonstrations were bad.
Was there a poll taken by the media?
I'm sure there was with George Harris and everyone else, and they could say so many, a certain percentage was for the war and a certain percentage was not.
I don't recall any of the numbers now, but I'm sure that the majority of the people supported the war effort initially.
And as the war dragged on, and I mean month by month, that supported the time.
And at some point, I'm sure it was less than 50% of the nation.
I know that supported the war.
I know whenever ICAF came home from Vietnam in 1969, the general reaction,
people in my home from the people in my hometown.
Well, I guess the war is necessary.
You guys are there for a good cause, but I just wish the war would be over.
The Americans are the nature of the Americans is we like to get in and do something quickly.
Be done with it, whether it's in business or anything else.
And I think that was the general attitude toward war.
Let's get in and get this thing over with so we can put it behind us.
Were there specific liberal or conservative separations in the field, like groups of individuals who did believe in one way and groups that believed in another way for the war and against the war?
Oh, I'm sure there were.
I'm sure there were individuals who believed that way.
When you're in a rifle company and you're out in the field, though, everyone's life depends on how well the fella next to him does his job.
It's called survival.
You don't choose teams, you just decide to debate when you're out there in the field, because that's the wrong time.
When I was in the field the whole time, we were back in the rear area, club, drinking a few beers.
I'm sure they've got decent debates like that.
But we had a job to do.
As I say, our survival depended on everyone doing their job.
Were there many racial problems between whites, blacks, and Vietnamese in the field?
Well, again, we didn't operate with the Vietnamese, so I didn't see any racial problems with the Americans and the Vietnamese.
And out in the field, there were no racial problems.
I would not have tolerated him.
When I say that, I wouldn't have.
He said, what would I have done?
Had I had problems?
I don't know.
But I didn't have any problems.
I do know back in the rear area, the blacks would congregate in one area and do their thing.
I just don't have any first-hand experience.
But where everyone's life depends on the fellow next to him, and if he's in a combat situation, we just don't have that problem.
I'm talking about infantry company, not civil.
The guy that you share a boxhole with, if you're white, may be black.
And the color of the skin doesn't make any difference when you're in that situation.
I had one platoon that was led by a black sergeant, one of the finest men I know, a tremendous leader, and he had no trouble at all running that platoon.
When I was a sergeant running a platoon, I had a shortage of staff, non-commissioned officers, and this platoon leader went back to the United States
Three weeks leave, and it took him a while to get back, but this black sergeant ran the platoon for about five weeks, and I was lost in responsibility for a young man.
My weapons platoon commander was a black staff sergeant, and he had no problems.
So out in the field, I just didn't experience any problems.
